ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Drafting and writing papers, editing techniques.
I learned how to actually write a college essay!
How to write an academic paper, read scholarly articles and analyze text/quotes
Reading and analyzing academic texts in the social sciences, academic writing, and the complexities of urbanism in America and around the world.

College-level writing, drafting and outlining skills, making analytic arguments, close reading, and discussion
Learning about (mostly) American cities and dynamics surrounding urbanism and the structure of our cities.
I learned more about college-level academic writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: My writing skills improved a lot, small class meant everyone got personal feedback.
Weakness: The high number of 114 classes meant that there is a chance you might not enjoy the 114 class you have if it was one of your last choices.
Weaknesses: Essays should be spaced out more

Strengths: Good, speedy feedback on papers. Most readings are interesting
Weaknesses: Part of the final paper is a creative project based on your research paper, with a presentation. The project felt a little rushed and the reflection on it also felt a little unnecessary.

Strengths: Pam is easily the biggest strength of this course. She's really interesting and obviously knows a lot about cities and writing. Also, the material is very interesting, hard to be bored.
Weaknesses: The time frame on essays, from initial assignment to submission, can make it hard to put forth the best possible work. Also, classroom discussions sometimes felt less like seminars and more like lectures with some questions in between.

Strength: Collaborative and conversational learning format in class
Weakness: Essay timing spacing, first two essays felt semi-rushed while final essay had a good amount of time.
Strength: Focus on cities and urbanism, interesting and relevant topic that focuses on world around us and Yale.
Could improve: Potentially more immersion oppuritunities in New Haven. Grounding essay and research work in real life (more work like Essay 3 prompt).

Strengths: Comprehensive and learned a lot about academic writing
Weaknesses: Kind of random in terms of city concepts

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, taking a 114 freshman year is very important to a student of any major at Yale.
Yes, it is challenging but worth it.

Yes, if you haven't done a lot of academic reading/or writing this is a good class. Conceptually, the first two papers (second more than first) are a little bit hard to grasp, but the research paper is nicely paced and there are a lot of workshops/exercises to help you through it.
Yes. This class is very interesting and gives you a solid foundation in academic writing.

Yes, great class to improve college-level scholarly writing and writing skills in general.
Excellent course and elective for Urban Studies majors. Great overview of general themes of urban renewal and city decay and structures.
Yes if they want to learn about the basics of academic writing
